|title=Ancient Nepal |date=2006 |publisher=The Department |language=ne}}</ref> Kathmandu is one of the eight districts of [[Bagmati Zone]] and is located in Central Northern Part of [[Nepal]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://ddckathmandu.gov.np/ne-brief-introduction/ |title=संक्षिप्त परिचय : काठमाडौं |date=2017-09-07 |website=ddckathmandu.gov.np |language=ne |access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref> Kathmandu is a historically rich city and Hindu temples are the main attraction of this district. The monument list below is populated using the authentic information at Department of Archaeology.

revision.text:
This is the '''list of tourist attractions in [[Taipei]]''', [[capital city]] of [[Taiwan]].
[[File:Taipei228PeaceMemorialPark.jpg|thumb|400px|right|[[228 Peace Memorial Park]] with the [[National Taiwan Museum]] stands near the [[Presidential Office Building, Taipei|Presidential Office Building]].]]
== Notable buildings before 1945 == [[Image:Longshan Temple, Taipei 01.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Mengjia Longshan Temple|Longshan Temple]] was built in 1738.]] [[Image:taiwan.ntnu.concerthall.altonthompson.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Lecture hall at the [[National Taiwan Normal University]]. A number of Taipei campus structures date from Taiwan's period of [[Taiwan under Japanese rule|Japanese rule]].]] [[File:NTU Hospital.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Original home of the [[National Taiwan University Hospital]]]] * [[Dalongdong Baoan Temple]] (Datong) * [[Lin An Tai Historical House and Museum]] (Zhongshan) * [[Mengjia Longshan Temple|Longshan Temple]] (Wanhua) * [[National Taiwan Normal University]]: Lecture and Recital Hall (Da'an/Guting) * [[National Taiwan University]]: Library (Gongguan) * [[National Taiwan University]]: Original Hospital (Zhongzheng) * [[Taipei City Wall|North Gate]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Presidential Office Building, Taipei|Presidential Office Building]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Taipei Confucius Temple]] (Datong) * [[Xiahai City God Temple]] (Datong) * [[Red House Theater|Ximen Redhouse]] (Wanhua) * [[Hsing Tian Kong|Xingtian Temple]] (Zhongshan) * [[Yangmingshan National Park|Yangmingshan]] Historical Structures * [[Chi Nan Temple|Zhinan Temple]] (Wenshan)
== Notable buildings since 1945 == [[File:Chiang Kai-shek memorial amk.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall]] dates from Taiwan's [[Martial_law_in_Taiwan|martial law period]]. The plaza, now [[Liberty Square (Taipei)|Liberty Square]], hosted [[Wild Lily student movement|mass democracy rallies]] in 1990.]] [[File:Taipei101.portrait.altonthompson.jpg|thumb|right|[[Taipei 101]], built in a newly [[democracy|democratic]] Taiwan, was the first skyscraper to break the half-kilometer mark in height.]] * [[Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall]] at [[Liberty Square (Taipei)|Liberty Square]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Former American Consulate in Taipei]] (Zhongshan) * [[Guling Street Avant-garde Theatre]] (Zhongzheng) * [[National Revolutionary Martyrs' Shrine]] (Zhongshan) * [[National Theater and Concert Hall, Republic of China|National Theater and Concert Hall]] at [[Liberty Square (Taipei)|Liberty Square]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Shin Kong Life Tower]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall]] (Xinyi) * [[Taipei 101]] (Xinyi)
== Museums == {{See also|List of museums in Taiwan}} [[Image:National Taiwan Museum front 20070912.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[National Taiwan Museum]]]] [[Image:National Museum of History (Repulic of China).jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[National Museum of History]]]] [[Image:Taipei-fine-arts-museum.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Taipei Fine Arts Museum]]]] * [[Aurora Art Museum]] (Songshan) * [[Beitou Hot Spring Museum]] (Beitou) * [[Chang Foundation Museum]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Cheng Kung Senior High School]] Insect Museum (Zhongzheng) * [[Children's Art Museum in Taipei]] (Shilin) * Children's Museum of Transportation (Zhongzheng) * China Ceramics Museum (Beitou) * [[Customs Museum]] (Datong) * Dadaocheng Puppet Theatre Museum (Datong) * [[Fire Safety Museum of Taipei City Fire Department]] (Neihu) * Fo Guang Yuan Art Gallery (Songshan) * Forestry Exhibition Hall (Zhongzheng) * [[Hong-gah Museum]] (Beitou) * [[Hwa Kang Museum]] (Shilin) * [[Ketagalan Culture Center]] (Beitou) * [[Lin An Tai Historical House and Museum]] (Zhongshan) * [[Lin Liu-hsin Puppet Theatre Museum]] (Datong) * [[Miniatures Museum of Taiwan]] (Zhongshan) * [[MoCA Taipei|Museum of Contemporary Art Taipei]] (Datong) * Museum of the Institute of History and Philosophy, [[Academia Sinica]] (Nangang) * [[Museum of Jade Art]] (Zhongshan) * [[National Museum of History]], Nanhai Campus (Zhongzheng) * [[National Palace Museum]] (Shilin) * [[National Taiwan Museum]] (Zhongzheng) * [[National Taiwan Science Education Center]] (Shilin) * [[Chunghwa Postal Museum|Postal Museum]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Republic of China Armed Forces Museum]] (Zhongzheng) * Robot Museum (Beitou) * [[Shung Ye Museum of Formosan Aborigines]] (Shilin) * [[Suho Paper Memorial Museum]] (Zhongshan) * [[228 Peace Memorial Park|Taipei 228 Memorial Museum]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Taipei Artist Village]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Taipei Astronomical Museum]] (Shilin) * [[Taipei Fine Arts Museum]] (Zhongshan) * [[Taipei Story House]] (Zhongshan) * [[Taipei Water Park]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Beitou Museum|Taiwan Folk Arts Museum]] (Beitou) * [[Taiwan Land Reform Museum]] * [[Taiwan Storyland]] (Zhongzheng) * Taiwan Television Exposition (Songshan) * [[Tittot Glass Art Museum]] (Beitou) * Wan Fang Arts Museum (Wenshan) * Wei Chin-Yuan Musical Instruments Museum (Songshan) * YuYuYang Museum (Zhongzheng)
==Public places== * Digital Art Center, Taipei (Shilin) * [[Discovery Center of Taipei]] (Xinyi) * Hakka Culture Hall of Taipei (Xinyi) * Heritage and Culture Education Center of Taipei (Wanhua) * [[Liberty Square (Taipei)|Liberty Square]]: Plaza and Parks * Novel Hall for Performing Arts (Xinyi) * Puppetry Art Center of Taipei (Songshan) * Taipei Children's Recreation Center (Zhongshan) * Taipei Costume Cultural Center (Wanhua) * Taipei Cultural Center (Songshan) * Young Party (Zhongzheng)
== Urban parks == * [[228 Peace Memorial Park]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Daan Forest Park]] (Daan) * [[Dahu Park]] (Neihu) * [[Liberty Square (Taipei)|Liberty Square]]: Parks * [[Shilin Official Residence|Shilin Residence Park and Gardens]] (Shilin) * [[Taipei Botanical Garden]] (Zhongzheng) * [[Taipei Zoo]] (Wenshan)
==National park and nature preserve== * [[Yangmingshan]]
== Night markets == {{main|List of night markets in Taiwan}} * [[Dihua Street]] (迪化街) (Datong) * [[Gongguan Night Market]] (公館夜市) * [[Huaxi Street Tourist Night Market]] (Snake Alley) (華西街)(Wanhua) * [[Jingmei Night Market]] (景美夜市) (Wenshan) * [[Liaoning Street Night Market]] (遼寧街夜市) (Zhongshan) * [[Ningxia Night Market]] (寧夏夜市) (Datong) * [[Raohe Street Night Market]] (饒河街觀光夜市) (Songshan) * [[Shida Night Market]] (師大夜市) (Daan) * [[Shilin Night Market]] (士林夜市) (Shilin) * [[Tonghua Night Market]] (通化街夜市) (Daan) * [[Ximending]] (西門町) (Wanhua)
==Others== * [[Beitou Hot Springs]] (Beitou) * [[Dihua Street]] (Datong) * [[Maokong]] (Wenshan)
==See also== * [[List of tourist attractions in Taiwan]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Roman Catholic Mariology to [[:Category:Catholic Mariology]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{For|the opera singer|Mary Garden}} [[File:VirginMaryGarden.png|thumb|right|Garden at [[Saint Mary's University of Minnesota]]]] [[File:John S. Stokes, Jr. in Mary Garden.jpg|thumb|[http://ecommons.udayton.edu/imri_stokes_photos/6/ John S. Stokes, Jr. in his Mary Garden, 1982]. Image courtesy of [http://ecommons.udayton.edu/imri_stokes/ John Stokes and Mary's Gardens Collection], University of Dayton Libraries.]]
A '''Mary garden''' is a small [[sacred garden]] enclosing a statue or shrine of the [[Virgin Mary]], who is known to many [[Christian]]s as the [[Blessed Virgin Mary (Roman Catholic)|Blessed Virgin]], [[Blessed Virgin Mary (Roman Catholic)|Our Lady]], or the [[Mother of God]].<ref>''Ann Ball, 2003 Encyclopedia of Catholic Devotions and Practices'' {{ISBN|0-87973-910-X}} page 341</ref> In the [[New Testament]], Mary is the mother of [[Jesus of Nazareth]]. Mary gardens are most common to those Christian denominations which hold the Virgin Mary in special esteem, particularly [[Roman Catholic]]s and [[Anglican]]s.
==History== {{Roman Catholic Mariology}} The practice originated among monasteries and convents in [[medieval Europe]]. During the Middle Ages, people saw reminders of Mary in the flowers and herbs growing around them.<ref name=krymow>[https://www.franciscanmedia.org/honoring-mary-in-your-garden/ Krymow, Vincenzina and Frisk, M. Jean. "Honoring Mary in Your Garden", St. Anthony Messenger]</ref><ref name="roberson"> [https://www.udayton.edu/imri/mary/h/herbs-and-flowers-of-the-virgin-mary.php/ "Herbs and Flowers of the Virgin Mary", Marian Library, University of Dayton]</ref> The first reference to an actual garden dedicated to Mary is from the life of [[Saint Fiacre|St. Fiacre]], Irish patron saint of gardening, who planted and tended a garden around the oratory to Our Lady he built at his famous hospice for the poor and infirm in France in the 7th Century. The first record of a flower actually named for Mary is that of "seint mary gouldes" (St. Mary's Gold or Marygold) for the [[Pot Marigold]] or ''[[Calendula]]'', in a 1373 English recipe for a potion to ward off the plague.<ref name=johnsstokes>[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/HISTPERS.HTM Stokes Jr., John S., "Mary Gardens Historical Perspective", 1991]</ref>
==Modern revival== The first such garden open to the public in the United States was founded in 1932 at St. Joseph's Church, [[Woods Hole]], [[Cape Cod]], [[Massachusetts]].<ref name=stokes>[https://udayton.edu/imri/mary/m/mary-garden-woods-hole-mass.php "Mary's Gardens", Marian Library, University of Dayton]</ref> This garden was founded by Frances Crane Lillie, a summer resident of Woods Hole. It was Lillie's recollection of the symbolic herbs and flowers that she had encountered in England that prompted her to conceive and donate a Mary Garden to St. Joseph's Church.<ref>[https://www.udayton.edu/imri/mary/h/herbs-and-flowers-of-the-virgin-mary.php/ "The Herbs and Flowers of the Virgin Mary", Marian Library, University of Dayton]</ref>
Inspired by the St. Joseph's Mary Garden in Woods Hole, Edward A. G. McTague and John S. Stokes, Jr. founded "Mary's Gardens" of Philadelphia in 1951 as a project to research flowers identified with Mary, and make available seeds and plant source information for starting Mary Gardens. They also initiated a series of articles in religious publications to encourage the planting of Mary gardens.<ref>[http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/HISTPERS.htm/ Stokes Jr., John S., "Mary Gardens in Historical Perspective", 1991]</ref>
==Description== A Mary garden may be a single indoor pot, a large plot outdoors, or anything in between. They can be found at parishes, schools, homes, shrines, convents and other institutions.<ref name=denver>[http://www.archden.org/index.cfm/ID/1943 Filby, Julie. "Mary garden: a flower-enhanced tranquil spot to reflect on the Blessed Mother", ''Denver Catholic Register'', April 22,2009]</ref>
The statue of Mary, sometimes holding the [[Madonna and Child|Infant Christ]], is central to the garden. Select flowers, shrubs, and trees associated with the legends about Mary are planted in the garden. Such plants may include [[Bay Laurel|laurel tree]]s, strawberries, [[Cypripedioideae|ladyslippers]], [[lily of the valley|lilies of the valley]], [[peony|peonies]], [[Viola (plant)|violet]]s, [[Iris (plant)|iris]]es and roses, all of which are identified as [[Flower#Symbolism|symbolic]] and significant in the story of Mary as recounted in the Bible and other Christian stories. Gardens may have benches and a facility for lighting [[votive candle]]s.
It demonstrates [[Roman Catholic devotions|devotional]] commitment through the [[spiritual practice]] of designing, building and maintaining the garden and for the attendance, [[contemplation]], and prayers of visitors. Mary gardens are similar to the [[Zen]] [[Zen garden|meditation gardens]] found in the [[Buddhist]] tradition, with the exception that a Mary Garden pays homage to a person, the Virgin Mary, whereas a meditation garden in the East Asian traditions does not focus on a person.<ref>[http://www.moplants.com/archives/mary_garden.php Create a Mary Garden]</ref><ref name="krymow"/>
==Flowers associated with Mary== More than 30 flowers and herbs are connected to legends about Mary’s life.<ref name="krymow"/> *Lily: Mary was associated with this passage from the Song of Songs: "I am the Rose of Sharon, the lily of the valleys." (2:1) A legend from the second century says that when Mary's tomb was opened to show Thomas that her body had been assumed into heaven, it was filled with roses and lilies.<ref name="udayton.edu">[https://www.udayton.edu/imri/mary/m/may-flowers.php/ "May flowers", Marian Library, University of Dayton]</ref> * Columbine: also known as "Our Lady's Shoes", is said to have sprung up wherever Mary’s foot touched the ground on her way to visit her cousin Elizabeth.<ref name="krymow"/> * Lavender: “Mary’s Drying Plant” was said to have received its scent after Mary laid Jesus’ clothes on it to dry.<ref>[http://www.archden.org/index.cfm/ID/1943/ Filby, Julie. "Mary garden: a flower-enhanced tranquil spot to reflect on the Blessed Mother", ''Denver Catholic Register'', April 22,2009]</ref> * Madonna Lily: The angel Gabriel is said to have been holding a lily, representing purity, when he appeared to Mary to announce she would bear a child; lilies are often included in artistic renditions of the annunciation.<ref name="denver"/> * The marigold was called "Mary's Gold" by early Christians who placed the flowers around statues of Mary, offering the blossoms in place of coins. A legend says that during the flight into Egypt the Holy Family was accosted by a band of thieves. They took Mary's purse and when they opened it, marigolds fell out.<ref name="udayton.edu"/> * The violet is associated with humility and became known as "Our Lady's Modesty". It was said to have blossomed when Mary replied to the Angel Gabriel, "I am the handmaid of the Lord."<ref name="udayton.edu"/> *Irises were used in Mary Gardens. The blade-shaped foliage denotes the sorrows which 'pierced her heart.'
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Gardenofmary.JPG|Mary Garden at the [[Basilica of St. Lawrence, Asheville|Basilica of St. Lawrence]] in [[Asheville, North Carolina]] Image:St. Michael's College School.JPG|Mary garden at [[St. Michael's College School]] in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada Image:Our Lady of Peace, West Point, NY.JPG|Mary garden at [[Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity (West Point)|Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity]] at the [[West Point Military Academy]] in [[New York (state)|New York]]. </gallery>
==See also== *[[Anglican devotions]] *[[Catholic devotions]] *[[Sacramentals]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == *[http://ecommons.udayton.edu/imri_stokes/''John Stokes and Mary's Gardens Collection''], records of John Stokes' organization, Mary Gardens. University of Dayton Libraries.
{{Horticulture and gardening}}
[[Category:Anglican Mariology]] [[Category:Gardens in religion]] [[Category:Marian devotions]] [[Category:Marian shrines]] [[Category:Religious places]] [[Category:Catholic Mariology]]

{{Infobox mountain | name = Mount Titano | photo = Monte Titano.jpg | photo_caption = Monte Titano and three fortresses on top of it can be seen from many kilometers away. | photo_size = 250 | elevation_m = 739 | elevation_ref = <ref name="pb">[http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=10183 "Mount Titano" on Peakbagger.com] Retrieved 30 September 2011</ref> | prominence_m = 189 | prominence_ref = <ref name="pb"/> | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]] | map = San Marino | map_caption = Location in San Marino | map_size = 220 | label_position = right | location = [[San Marino]] | range = [[Apennines]] | coordinates = {{coord|43|55|42|N|12|27|08|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = | age = | last_eruption = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = |embedded={{designation list | embed=yes | designation1 = WHS | designation1_offname = [[City of San Marino|San Marino Historic Centre]] and Mount Titano | designation1_date = 2008 <small>(32nd [[World Heritage Committee|session]])</small> | designation1_type = Cultural | designation1_criteria = iii | designation1_number = [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1245 1245] | designation1_free1name = State Party | designation1_free1value = [[San Marino]] | designation1_free2name = Region | designation1_free2value = [[List of World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]] }} }}
'''Monte Titano''' ("Mount Titan")<ref name="Spink & Son">{{cite book|author=Spink & Son|title=The Numismatic circular|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WAkrAAAAMAAJ&pg=PT531|volume=6–7|year=1898|language=Italian|page=531}}</ref> is a mountain of the [[Apennine Mountains|Apennines]] and the highest peak in [[San Marino]]. It stands at {{convert|739|m|ft|abbr=on}} [[above mean sea level|above sea level]]<ref>Official Italian 1:25,000 mapping; other sources give slightly higher figures.</ref> and is located immediately to the east of the capital, [[San Marino, San Marino|San Marino]]. It was inscribed as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] in 2008 under the combined title "San Marino Historic Centre and Mount Titano". Inscribed under reference no. 1245 criteria iii, the two together encompass an area of 55 ha with a buffer zone of 167 ha. It encompasses Mount Titano and the other structures such as the fortification towers, walls, gates and bastions, as well as a neo-classical basilica located on it and its slopes forming a small but unique urban conglomerate.<ref name=unesco>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1245|title=San Marino Historic Centre and Mount Titano|accessdate=2010-11-03|publisher=UNESCO.org}}</ref><ref name=mount>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/archive/advisory_body_evaluation/1245.pdf|format=pdf|title=San Marino|accessdate=2010-11-03|publisher=UNESCO.org}}</ref>
Straddled on the ridge of Mount Titano is the city of San Marino of the Republic of San Marino, the [[History of San Marino|history of which]] dates from the early 4th century. According to the legend related to the Mount and its precincts a small monastery existed on top of the Mount during the 8th century. The mountainous landscape provides excellent views of its surroundings, and its isolated location ensured the needed seclusion for San Marino to survive as a Republic over the past several centuries.<ref name=mount/><ref name=travel>{{Cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/521449/San-Marino/236529/Geography?anchor=ref101628|title= Travel & Geography: Mount Titano|accessdate=2010-11-03|encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref>
==Trivia==
The mountain has three peaks; on each is one of [[The Three Towers of San Marino]]. [[Saint Marinus]] is always represented with Mount Titano in his hands.<ref name=travel/><ref name= Haggett >{{cite encyclopedia|last= Haggett |first= Peter|encyclopedia= Encyclopedia of world geography, Volume 11|page=1461|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qQgXLCQVFXsC&pg=PA1461|publisher= Marshall Cavendish|year=2002|isbn=0-7614-7300-9}}</ref><ref name=discover>{{Cite web|url=http://geography.howstuffworks.com/europe/geography-of-san-marino.htm|title= Geography of San Marino|accessdate=2010-11-03|publisher=How Discoveryworks: A Discovery Company}}{{Unreliable source?|date=November 2010}}</ref>
==Geography and environment== Monte Titano is located in central [[San Marino]] (seen in maps in rough rectangular shape), to the southeast of the [[City of San Marino]] and to the north of the village of [[Murata (San Marino)|Murata]], at a distance of {{convert|10|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the Adriatic Coast.<ref name=travel/><ref name=Beyond>{{Cite web|url=http://www.visitsanmarino.com/default.asp?id=84 |title=Beyond geography |accessdate=2010-11-03 |publisher=Republic Di Martino: Visitsanmarino.com |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617142910/http://www.visitsanmarino.com/default.asp?id=84 |archivedate=June 17, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite map|title=[[Google Maps]]|publisher=Google|accessdate=November 2, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite map|title=[[Bing Maps]]|publisher= [[Microsoft]] and [[Harris Corporation]] Earthstar Geographics LLC|accessdate=November 2, 2010}}</ref> Monte Titano looks like a rugged limestone outcrop, located only 13 kilometres (a figure of 10 km is mentioned in another reference) from the [[Adriatic Sea]] on the Apennines. Although the highest point is 739 metres above sea level, the rocky outcrop is about 200 metres in height at most. From the top of Monte Titano views of the entire nation of San Marino and further afield can be viewed scenically. The mountain gives birth to several streams, including the [[San Marino River]], which flows down its western slope through a broad valley<ref>''Scottish geographical magazine'', Volumes 39–40, Royal Scottish Geographical Society, (1923)</ref> and flows into the Marecchia River, through [[Marecchia Torello]] and into the Adriatic Sea {{convert|23|km|mi|abbr=on}} away and the [[Cando River]], born in [[Marano]], which flows into the Adriatic coast between [[Rimini]] and [[Riccione Ausa]]. The terrain has fertile soils in Emilia Romagna plain and soft rolling hills in the Marche and Montefeltro region. The mountain dips into the calm Adriatic sea.<ref name=travel/><ref name =Beyond/>
During the [[Tertiary|Tertiary era]], the area where San Marino lies was the sea. Violent earthquakes caused major upheavals in the Earth's surface. Because of these intensive earthquakes, a mass of rock situated about {{convert|80|km|mi|abbr=on}} from the mountain, was lifted and slid slowly toward the Adriatic Sea. This mass of rock gave rise to various mountains, including Mount Titano. The vertebrate fossils found on the slopes of Mount Titano are mostly aquatic in origin, because of the fact this rock was once located underneath the sea in its current spot. Fossils of various fish, especially the fossils of [[shark teeth]] have been discovered on Monte Titano, with many dated to the [[Miocene]] period.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lawley, R.|year=1880|title=Selache manzoni n. sp. – Dente fossile délia molassa miocenica del Monte Titano (Repubblica di San Marino).|publisher=Atti della Società Toscana di Scienze Naturali, 5: |pages=167–172, fig. 1–3}}</ref> The most important fossil discovery is that of a whale, which is now preserved in the [[Bologna Archaeological Museum]].
The precincts of Monte Titano and the San Marino city experiences mild temperate climate; the maximum temperatures reported is of 79 °F (26 °C) in summer while the minimum is 19 °F (−7 °C) in winter. Annual precipitation varies from about 22 inches (560 mm) to 32 inches (800 mm).
==Flora and fauna== Set in the Mediterranean zone the vegetation is typical influenced by elevation variations. Numerous trees inhabit the mountain, including [[chestnut]]s, [[oak]]s, [[laburnum]], [[cypress]], [[fir tree]]s and some shrubs and [[asparagus]], typical of the driest areas, such as the territory in the [[Three Towers of San Marino]] vicinity. On the cliffs of Mount Titano is also found ''[[Ephedra Nebrodensis]]'', a plant typical of [[Sicily]] and [[Sardinia]].
Wildlife is represented by all classes of vertebrates and, given the characteristics of the mountainous territory, birds and mammals are the most common animals. In relation to birds, several can be mentioned such as the [[kestrel]], [[barn owl]], [[owl]], [[tawny owl]], the [[magpie]] and [[buzzard]]s. Common animal life includes [[roe deer]], [[wild boar]], [[deer]], [[weasel]]s, [[marten]], [[porcupine]], [[hare]], [[hedgehog]]s, [[European polecat|polecats]], [[badger]]s and [[fox]]es.<ref name=travel/>
==Protected area== Since 2008, Monte Titano was allocated as a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]], in tandem with the historic centre of San Marino. The reason given by the Committee refers to "witnessing the continuity of a free republic since Middle Ages. "<ref name="UNESCO">{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1245/|title=San Marino|publisher=[[UNESCO]]|accessdate=November 2, 2010}}</ref> This heritage site include the towers, walls, gates and bastions of the City of San Marino, the [[Basilica di San Marino]] of the nineteenth century, some convents of the fourteenth and sixteenth centuries, the eighteenth century [[Teatro Titano]] Theatre and the [[Palazzo Pubblico]] of the nineteenth century.<ref name="UNESCO"/> {{double image|left|Fortress of Guaita 2013-09-19.jpg|240|Sanmarino5.jpg|220|Views from the top of Monte Titano}} {{double image|right|Coat of arms of San Marino.svg|160|Flag of San Marino.svg|180|Left: The coat of arms depicting the three towers on Mount Titano. Right: National Flag of San Marino with the Coat of Arms in the centre}} {{clear}}
==Culture== {{Further|San Marino}} The layout of the Mount Titano presents three peaks, each crowned by ancient towers named Guaita, Cesta and Montale, with triple fortifications that enclose the capital city. Each tower in turn has a metal vane fixed on it which is in the shape of an ostrich plume, ("perhaps a pun on the Italian ''penne'', meaning "plumes") which is attributed to the name of the mountains. Those three towers are represented in the coat of arms of in the central part of the National Flag (horizontal white and blue) of the country (which has a width to length ratio of 3 to 4). The capital city is set on the western side of Mount Titano.<ref name=travel/><ref name=flag>{{Cite encyclopedia |url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1355487/San-Marino-flag-of?anchor=ref716883|title= Flag of San Marino|accessdate=2010-11-03|encyclopedia =Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref> An urban network of roads links the fortresses.<ref name=discover/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

[[File:Oscar Ferdinand Peschel00.jpg|right|thumb|Oscar Ferdinand Peschel (1826-1875)]] '''Oscar Ferdinand Peschel''' (17 March 1826, [[Dresden]] – 13 August 1875, [[Leipzig]]) was a German [[geographer]] and [[anthropologist]].<ref>The little encyclopedia Encyclios-Verlag, Zurich, 1950, Volume 2, Page 342</ref>
==Biography==
As the son of an officer and teacher at the local [[military school]], Peschel studied law from 1845 to 1848 in Leipzig and [[Heidelberg]]. In 1850 he joined the editorial staff of the ''Augsburger Allgemeine Zeitung''. In 1854 he took over the editorship for the journal ''Das Ausland'',<ref name=DB>[http://www.deutsche-biographie.de/sfz94751.html Peschel, Oscar Ferdinand] @ NDB/ADB Deutsche Biographie</ref> of which he continued until the end of March 1871.
In 1871 he became a full professor of the newly established chair of geography at the [[University of Leipzig]].<ref name=DB/> This is thus the fourth oldest chair of geography in Germany after [[University of Berlin|Berlin]], [[University of Göttingen|Göttingen]] and [[University of Bonn|Bonn]].<ref>Sabine Höhler: World areas. Campus-Verlag , 2005, page 122</ref>
Peschel 1858 corresponding member of the [[Bavarian Academy of Sciences]]. Shortly before his death he was also a regular member of the Royal Saxon Society of Sciences in Leipzig.<ref>[http://www.uni-leipzig.de/unigeschichte/professorenkatalog/leipzig/Peschel_940.pdf Universität Leipzig] (biographical sketch)</ref>
==Racial classification==
In 1871 he became a full Professor of the newly established Chair of Geography at the [[University of Leipzig]], he was also a prominent corresponding member of the [[Bavarian Academy of Sciences]]. Peschel is most remembered for his book ''The Races of Man: and their geographical distribution'' (1876) which classifies man into seven races: [[Australoids]], ([[Papuan people|Papuans]]), ([[Melanesians]]), [[Mongoloids]], [[Dravidians]], [[Bushmen]] ([[Capoid race|Capoids]]), [[Negroids]] and [[Mediterranean race|Mediterraneans]] ([[Caucasoids]] - the race itself is divided by Peschel into the Hamite, Semite, and Indo-European families).
== Selected works == * ''Geschichte des Zeitalters der Entdeckungen'', 1858 - History of the eras of discovery. * ''Geschichte der erdkunde'', 1865 - History of geography. * ''Neue Probleme der vergleichenden Erdkunde als versuch einer Morphologie de Erdoberfläche'', 1870 - New problems of comparative geography in regards to the morphology of the earth's surface. * ''Völkerkunde'', 1874 - [[Ethnology]]. * "The races of man : and their geographical distribution", 1876. * ''Abhandlungen zur Erd- und Völkerkunde'', 1877 - On geography and ethnology.<ref>[http://classify.oclc.org/classify2/ClassifyDemo?search-author-txt=%22Peschel%2C+Oscar%2C+1826-1875+%22 OCLC Classify] (published works)</ref>
==Legacy== [[Peschel Island]] in the [[Svalbard]] archipelago is named after Peschel.<ref>[http://placenames.npolar.no/stadnamn/Peschel%C3%B8ya Stadnamn i norske polarområde: Pescheløya (Svalbard).]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} * Parts of this article are based on text of an equivalent article at the [[German Wikipedia]]. * Rainer W. Gardener, The development of scientific geography in Saxony under the influence of Oscar Peschel, Delitsch Otto and Ferdinand von Richthofen, typescript written. Diss. Leipzig 1993. *Friedrich Ratzel: Peschel, Oscar . In: Allgemeine Deutsche Biographie (ADB). * Friedrich Ratzel: Peschel, Oscar . General German Biography (ADB). Band 25, Duncker & Humblot, Leipzig 1887, S. 416–430. Volume 25, Duncker & Humblot, Leipzig 1887, pp. 416–430.

[[File:Petrusplancius.gif|thumb|200px|Petrus Plancius. J. Buys/Rein. Vinkoeles (1791)]]
'''Petrus Plancius''' (1552 – May 15, 1622) was a [[Dutch people|Dutch]]-[[Flemish people|Flemish]] [[astronomer]], [[Cartography|cartographer]] and [[clergyman]]. He was born as '''Pieter Platevoet''' in [[Dranouter]], now in [[Heuvelland]], [[West Flanders]]. He studied [[theology]] in Germany and England. At the age of 24 he became a [[Religious minister|minister]] in the [[Dutch Reformed Church]].
Because of fear of religious prosecution by the [[Inquisition]] Plancius fled from [[Brussels]] to [[Amsterdam]] after the city fell into Spanish hands in 1585. There he became interested in [[navigation]] and [[cartography]] and, being fortunate enough to have access to nautical charts recently brought from Portugal, he was soon recognized as an expert on the shipping routes to [[India]]. He strongly believed in the idea of a [[Northern Sea Route|North East passage]] until the failure of [[Willem Barentsz]]'s third voyage in 1597 seemed to preclude the possibility of such a route.
For [[History of cartography#Dutch celestial cartography in the Age of Exploration|his pioneering contributions in the history of celestial cartography]], Plancius is considered to be one of the notable figures in the [[Golden Age of Netherlandish cartography|Golden Age of Dutch/Netherlandish cartography]] (c. 1570s–1670s).
==Cartography== [[File:Petrus Plancius Instructing Students in the Science of Navigation.jpg|thumb|Petrus Plancius Instructing Students in the Science of Navigation, by [[David Vinckboons]]]] In 1592 Plancius published his best known world map titled "Nova et exacta Terrarum Tabula geographica et hydrographica".<ref>"New and exact geographic and hydrographic map of the world".</ref> Apart from maps, he published journals and navigational guides and developed a new method for determining [[longitude]]. He also introduced the [[Mercator projection]] for navigational maps.
Plancius was one of the founders of the [[Dutch East India Company]] for which he drew over 100 maps.
Plancius was closely acquainted with [[Henry Hudson]], an explorer of the [[New World]].
Plancius prepared the map, ''Exacta & accurata delinatio… regionibus China, Cauchinchina, Camboja, sive Champa, Syao, Malacca, Arracan & Pegu,'' published in [[Jan Huygen van Linschoten]]’s popular book, ''Itinerario'' (1596).<ref>Leo Bagrow, ''History of Cartography,'' revised and enlarged by R. A. Skelton, London, Watts, 1964, p.265. [http://nla.gov.au/nla.map-rm4335 Exacta & accurata delinatio cum orarum maritimarum tum etiam locorum terrestrium quæ in regionibus China, Cauchinchina, Camboja, sive Champa, Syao, Malacca, Arracan & Pegu] ; Cornelis Koeman, ''Jan Huygen Van Linschoten,'' Coimbra, Universidade de Coimbra Biblioteca Geral 1, 1984, Centro de Estudos de Historia e Cartografia, Vol.153, pp.39-41. Also in ''Revista da Universidade de Coimbra,'' vol.32, 1985, pp.27-47.</ref>
===Uranography=== In 1589 Plancius collaborated with the Amsterdam cartographer [[Jacob Floris van Langren]] on a 32.5-cm celestial globe, which, using the sparse information available about southern celestial features, for the first time depicted: [[Crux]] the southern cross, [[Triangulum Australe]] the southern triangle, and the [[Ferdinand Magellan|Magellanic Clouds]], [[Large Magellanic Cloud|Nubecula Major]] and [[Small Magellanic Cloud|Minor]].
In 1595 Plancius asked [[Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser]], the chief pilot on the ''Hollandia'', to make observations to fill in the blank area around the south celestial pole on European maps of the southern sky. Keyser died in [[Java (island)|Java]] the following year – the expedition had many casualties – but his catalogue of 135 [[star]]s,<ref name="knobel_dehoutman">[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/1917MNRAS..77..414K "On Frederick de Houtman's catalogue of southern stars, and the origin of the southern constellations"], by E. B. Knobel, 1917, the catalogue starting at [http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?bibcode=1917MNRAS..77..414K&db_key=AST&page_ind=7&plate_select=NO&data_type=GIF&type=SCREEN_GIF&classic=YES page 421]</ref> probably measured up with the help of explorer-colleague [[Frederick de Houtman]],<ref name="ridpath_ch1_c">[http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/startales1c.htm "Star Tales ― CHAPTER ONE continued..."] by [[Ian Ridpath]]</ref> was delivered to Plancius. These stars appear as 12 new southern [[constellation]]s,<ref name="ridpath_ch1_c"/> on a 35-cm celestial globe designed by Plancius in late 1597 (or early 1598) and produced in collaboration with the Amsterdam cartographer [[Jodocus Hondius|Jodocus Hondius the Elder]]. The 12 new constellations (mostly referring to animals and subjects described in natural history books and travellers' journals of his day) are [[Apis (constellation)|Apis]] the Bee (later changed to [[Musca]] by [[Lacaille]]), [[Apus]] the Bird of Paradise, [[Chamaeleon]], [[Dorado]] the Goldfish (or Swordfish), [[Grus (constellation)|Grus]] the Crane, [[Hydrus]] the Small Water Snake, [[Indus (constellation)|Indus]] the Indian, [[Pavo (constellation)|Pavo]] the Peacock, [[Phoenix (constellation)|Phoenix]], [[Triangulum Australe]] the Southern Triangle, [[Tucana]] the Toucan, and [[Volans]] the Flying Fish. (The Southern Triangle and Southern Cross were reported as asterisms by earlier navigators and appear on earlier charts,<ref name="Dekker">{{cite journal |last=Dekker |first=Elly |date=1987 |title=Early Explorations of the Southern Celestial Sky |url= |journal=Annals of Science |volume=44 |issue= |pages=439–470 |doi= 10.1080/00033798700200301|access-date= |bibcode = 1987AnSci..44..439D }}</ref> but the globe of 1598 is the first surviving source that plots their locations reasonably accurately.) Also notable is the inclusion of Achernar as Alpha Eridani.
These constellations, together with the constellation [[Columba (constellation)|Columba]] illustrated by Plancius on his large wall map of the world of 1592, were then incorporated in 1603 by [[Johann Bayer]] in his sky atlas, the ''[[Uranometria]]''.
In 1612 (or 1613) Plancius introduced the following eight constellations on a 26.5-cm celestial globe published in Amsterdam by [[Pieter van der Keere]]: [[Musca Borealis|Apes]] the Bee,<ref name="stoppa_plancius">[http://www.atlascoelestis.com/desu%20Plancius.htm Le costellazioni di Petrus Plancius], on Atlas Coelestis by Felice Stoppa</ref> [[Camelopardalis]] the Giraffe (often interpreted as a Camel),<ref name="stoppa_plancius"/> [[Cancer Minor]] the Small Crab, [[River Tigris (constellation)|Euphrates Fluvius et Tigris Fluvius]] the Rivers Euphrates and Tigris, [[Gallus (constellation)|Gallus]] the Cock, [[Jordanus (constellation)|Jordanis Fluvius]] the River Jordan, [[Monoceros]] the Unicorn<ref name="stoppa_plancius"/> and [[Sagitta Australis]] the Southern Arrow. Of the latter constellations, only [[Camelopardalis]] and [[Monoceros]] are still found on modern star charts, and recognized by the [[IAU]].<ref name="International Astronomical Union">[[Astronomical naming conventions#Names and boundaries of constellations]]</ref>
The [[minor planet]] 10648 Plancius commemorates his contributions in celestial and terrestrial cartography.
===Maps=== <gallery> 1590 Orbis Terrarum Plancius.jpg|Orbis Terrarum 1590 1594 Orbis Plancius 2,12 MB.jpg|Orbis Terrarum 1594 1592 4 Nova Doetecum mr.jpg| [[New France|Nova Francia]] .. Terra Nova 1592 1592 Insullae Moluc. Plancius.jpg| [[Maluku Islands|Insulae Moluccae]] 1592 </gallery>

revision.text:
{{short description|Rise of land masses that were depressed by the huge weight of ice sheets during the last glacial period}} [[File:PGR Paulson2007 Rate of Lithospheric Uplift due to PGR.png|thumb|550px|right|A model of present-day mass change due to post-glacial rebound and the reloading of the ocean basins with seawater. Blue and purple areas indicate rising due to the removal of the ice sheets. Yellow and red areas indicate falling as mantle material moved away from these areas in order to supply the rising areas, and because of the collapse of the [[forebulge]]s around the ice sheets.]]
[[File:Rebounding beach, among other things (9404384095).jpg|thumb|300px|This layered beach at [[Bathurst Inlet]], [[Nunavut]] is an example of post-glacial rebound after the last Ice Age. Little to no tide helped to form its layer-cake look. Isostatic rebound is still underway here.]]
'''Post-glacial rebound''' (also called '''isostatic rebound''' or '''crustal rebound''') is the rise of land masses after the lifting of the huge weight of [[ice sheet]]s during the [[last glacial period]], which had caused [[isostatic depression]]. Post-glacial rebound and isostatic depression are phases of '''glacial isostasy''' ('''glacial isostatic adjustment''', '''glacioisostasy'''), the deformation of the Earth's crust in response to changes in ice mass distribution.<ref name="MilneOthers2013a">{{cite encyclopedia|last1=Milne|first1=G.|last2=Shennan|first2=I.|title=Isostasy: Glaciation-Induced Sea-Level Change|editor1-last=Elias |editor1-first=Scott A. |editor2-last=Mock |editor2-first=Cary J.|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Quaternary Science|volume=3|year=2013|edition=2nd|doi=10.1016/B978-0-444-53643-3.00135-7|publisher=Elsevier|pages=452-459 |isbn=978-0-444-53643-3}}</ref> The direct raising effects of post-glacial rebound are readily apparent in parts of Northern [[Eurasia]], [[Northern America]], [[Patagonia]], and [[Antarctica]]. However, through the processes of ''ocean siphoning'' and ''continental levering'', the effects of post-glacial rebound on [[sea level]] are felt globally far from the locations of current and former ice sheets.<ref name="MilneOthers2008a">Milne, G.A., and J.X. Mitrovica (2008) ''Searching for eustasy in deglacial sea-level histories.'' Quaternary Science Reviews. 27:2292–2302.</ref>
==Overview== [[Image:Diagram showing historical levels of Lake Superior.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Changes in the elevation of [[Lake Superior]] due to glaciation and post-glacial rebound]] During the [[last glacial period]], much of [[northern Europe]], [[Asia]], [[North America]], [[Greenland]] and [[Antarctica]] was covered by [[ice sheet]]s, which reached up to three kilometres thick during the [[last glacial maximum|glacial maximum]] about 20,000 years ago. The enormous weight of this ice caused the surface of the [[Earth]]'s [[Crust (geology)|crust]] to deform and warp downward, forcing the [[viscoelastic]] [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] material to flow away from the loaded region. At the end of each [[glacial period]] when the [[glacier]]s retreated, the removal of this weight led to slow (and still ongoing) uplift or rebound of the land and the return flow of mantle material back under the [[deglaciation|deglaciated]] area. Due to the extreme [[viscosity]] of the mantle, it will take many thousands of years for the land to reach an [[Hydrostatic equilibrium|equilibrium]] level.
The uplift has taken place in two distinct stages. The initial uplift following deglaciation was almost immediate due to the [[Elasticity (physics)|elastic]] response of the crust as the ice load was removed. After this elastic phase, uplift proceeded by slow viscous flow at an [[exponential decay|exponentially]] decreasing rate.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} Today, typical uplift rates are of the order of 1 cm/year or less. In northern Europe, this is clearly shown by the [[GPS]] data obtained by the BIFROST GPS network.<ref name="johansson-2002">{{cite journal|last=Johansson |first=J.M. |display-authors=etal |date=2002 |title=Continuous GPS measurements of postglacial adjustment in Fennoscandia. 1. Geodetic results |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=107 |doi=10.1029/2001JB000400 |page=2157 |bibcode=2002JGRB..107.2157J}}</ref> Studies suggest that rebound will continue for at least another 10,000 years. The total uplift from the end of deglaciation depends on the local ice load and could be several hundred metres near the centre of rebound.
Recently, the term "post-glacial rebound" is gradually being replaced by the term "glacial isostatic adjustment". This is in recognition that the response of the Earth to glacial loading and unloading is not limited to the upward rebound movement, but also involves downward land movement, horizontal crustal motion,<ref name="johansson-2002" /><ref name="sella-etal-2007">{{cite journal |display-authors=4 |last=Sella |first=G.F. |author2=Stein, S. |author3=Dixon, T.H. |author4=Craymer, M. |author5=James, T.S. |author6=Mazzotti, S. |author7=Dokka, R.K. |date=2007 |title=Observation of glacial isostatic adjustment in "stable" North America with GPS |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=34 |pages=L02306 |doi=10.1029/2006GL027081 |bibcode=2007GeoRL..3402306S |issue=2}}</ref> changes in global sea levels<ref name="peltier-1998">{{cite journal |last=Peltier |first=W.R. |author-link=William Richard Peltier|date=1998 |title=Postglacial variations in the level of the sea: implications for climate dynamics and solid-earth geophysics |journal=Reviews of Geophysics |volume=36 |pages=603–689 |doi=10.1029/98RG02638 |bibcode=1998RvGeo..36..603P |issue=4}}</ref> and the Earth's gravity field,<ref name="mitrovica-peltier-1993">{{cite journal |last=Mitrovica |first=J.X. |author2=W.R. Peltier |date=1993 |title=Present-day secular variations in zonal harmonics of the Earth's geopotential |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=98 |pages=4509–4526 |doi=10.1029/92JB02700 |bibcode=1993JGR....98.4509M}}</ref> induced earthquakes,<ref name="wu-johnston-2000">{{cite journal |last=Wu |first=P. |author2=P. Johnston |date=2000 |title=Can deglaciation trigger earthquakes in N. America? |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=27 |pages=1323–1326 |doi=10.1029/1999GL011070 |bibcode=2000GeoRL..27.1323W |issue=9}}</ref> and changes in the Earth's rotation.<ref name="wu-peltier-1984">{{cite journal |last=Wu |first=P. |author2=W.R.Peltier |date=1984 |title=Pleistocene deglaciation and the earth's rotation: a new analysis |journal=Geophysical Journal of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=76 |pages=753–792 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-246X.1984.tb01920.x|bibcode=1984GeoJ...76..753W }}</ref> Another alternate term is "glacial isostasy", because the uplift near the centre of rebound is due to the tendency towards the restoration of isostatic equilibrium (as in the case of isostasy of mountains). Unfortunately, that term gives the wrong impression that isostatic equilibrium is somehow reached, so by appending "adjustment" at the end, the motion of restoration is emphasized.
==Effects== Post-glacial rebound produces measurable effects on vertical crustal motion, global sea levels, horizontal crustal motion, gravity field, Earth's rotation, crustal stress, and earthquakes. Studies of glacial rebound give us information about the flow law of mantle rocks, which is important to the study of mantle convection, [[plate tectonics]] and the thermal evolution of the Earth. It also gives insight into past ice sheet history, which is important to [[glaciology]], [[paleoclimate]], and changes in global sea level. Understanding postglacial rebound is also important to our ability to monitor recent global change.
===Vertical crustal motion=== [[Image:Suomi jaakauden jalkeen.png|thumb|200px|Much of modern [[Finland]] is former seabed or archipelago: illustrated are sea levels immediately after the last ice age.]] Erratic [[boulder]]s, [[U-shaped valley]]s, [[drumlin]]s, [[esker]]s, [[kettle lake]]s, [[bedrock]] [[Glacial striation|striation]]s are among the common signatures of the [[Ice Age]]. In addition, post-glacial rebound has caused numerous significant changes to coastlines and landscapes over the last several thousand years, and the effects continue to be significant.
In [[Sweden]], Lake [[Mälaren]] was formerly an arm of the [[Baltic Sea]], but uplift eventually cut it off and led to its becoming a [[freshwater]] [[lake]] in about the 12th century, at the time when [[Stockholm]] was founded at [[Slussen|its outlet]]. Marine seashells found in [[Lake Ontario]] sediments imply a similar event in prehistoric times. Other pronounced effects can be seen on the island of [[Öland]], Sweden, which has little topographic relief due to the presence of the very level [[Stora Alvaret]]. The rising land has caused the [[Iron Age]] settlement area to recede from the [[Baltic Sea]], making the present day villages on the west coast set back unexpectedly far from the shore. These effects are quite dramatic at the village of [[Alby, Öland|Alby]], for example, where the [[Iron Age]] inhabitants were known to subsist on substantial coastal fishing.
As a result of post-glacial rebound, the [[Gulf of Bothnia]] is predicted to eventually close up at [[Kvarken]] in more than 2,000 years.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tikkanen |first1=Matti |last2=Oksanen |first2=Juha |date=2002 |title=Late Weichselian and Holocene shore displacement history of the Baltic Sea in Finland |url=http://www.helsinki.fi/maantiede/geofi/fennia/demo/pages/oksanen.htm |journal=[[Fennia (journal)|Fennia]] |volume=180 |issue=1–2 |pages= |doi= |access-date=December 22, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171020130214/http://www.helsinki.fi/maantiede/geofi/fennia/demo/pages/oksanen.htm |archivedate=October 20, 2017 |df= }}</ref> The [[Kvarken]] is a [[UNESCO]] [[World Natural Heritage Site]], selected as a "type area" illustrating the effects of post-glacial rebound and the [[holocene glacial retreat]].
In several other [[Nordic Countries|Nordic]] ports, like [[Tornio]] and [[Pori]] (formerly at [[Ulvila]]), the harbour has had to be relocated several times. Place names in the coastal regions also illustrate the rising land: there are inland places named 'island', 'skerry', 'rock', 'point' and 'sound'. For example, [[Oulunsalo]] "island of [[Oulujoki]]"<ref name="ouloujoki">{{cite web |url=http://kaino.kotus.fi/www/verkkojulkaisut/julk125/oulunsalo/ |title=Oulunsalon kirkon seudun paikannimistö |language=Finnish |accessdate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080221110053/http://kaino.kotus.fi/www/verkkojulkaisut/julk125/oulunsalo/ |archivedate=2008-02-21 |df= }}</ref> is a peninsula, with inland names such as ''Koivukari'' "Birch Rock", ''Santaniemi'' "Sandy Cape", and ''Salmioja'' "the brook of the Sound". (Compare [http://kaino.kotus.fi/www/verkkojulkaisut/julk125/oulunsalo/oulunsalo_ennen.shtml] and [http://kaino.kotus.fi/www/verkkojulkaisut/julk125/oulunsalo/oulunsalo_nyt.shtml].) [[Image:Post-glacial rebound in British Isles.PNG|thumb|right|200px|Map of Post Glacial Rebound effects upon the land-level on the [[British Isles]].]] In [[Great Britain]], glaciation affected [[Scotland]] but not southern [[England]], and the post-glacial rebound of northern Great Britain (up to 10 cm per century) is causing a corresponding downward movement of the southern half of the island (up to 5 cm per century). This will eventually lead to an increased risk of [[flood]]s in southern England and south-western Ireland.<ref>{{cite news| last =Gray| first =Louise| title =England is sinking while Scotland rises above sea levels, according to new study| newspaper =Telegraph| date =7 October 2009| url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/earthnews/6226537/England-is-sinking-while-Scotland-rises-above-sea-levels-according-to-new-study.html| accessdate =10 April 2012| deadurl =no| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120617102426/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/earth/earthnews/6226537/England-is-sinking-while-Scotland-rises-above-sea-levels-according-to-new-study.html| archivedate =17 June 2012| df =}}</ref>
Since the glacial isostatic adjustment process causes the land to move relative to the sea, ancient shorelines are found to lie above present day sea level in areas that were once glaciated. On the other hand, places in the peripheral bulge area which was uplifted during glaciation now begins to subside. Therefore, ancient beaches are found below present day sea level in the bulge area. The "relative sea level data", which consists of height and age measurements of the ancient beaches around the world, tells us that glacial isostatic adjustment proceeded at a higher rate near the end of deglaciation than today.
The present-day uplift motion in northern Europe is also monitored by a [[GPS]] network called BIFROST.<ref name="johansson-2002" /><ref name="bifrost-harvard">{{cite web |url=http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/space_geodesy/BIFROST/radial_rates.html |title=Observed Radial Rates from GPS |work=BIFROST Associated GPS Networks |accessdate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67LIZE7mP?url=http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/space_geodesy/BIFROST/radial_rates.html |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }}</ref><ref name="bifrost">{{cite web |url=http://www.oso.chalmers.se/%7Ehgs/Bifrost_01/ |title=BIFROST |accessdate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67LIZiRER?url=http://froste.oso.chalmers.se/hgs//Bifrost_01/ |archivedate=2012-05-01 |df= }}</ref> Results of GPS data show a peak rate of about 11 mm/year in the north part of the [[Gulf of Bothnia]], but this uplift rate decreases away and becomes negative outside the former ice margin.
In the near field outside the former ice margin, the land sinks relative to the sea. This is the case along the east coast of the United States, where ancient beaches are found submerged below present day sea level and Florida is expected to be submerged in the future.<ref name="peltier-1998" /> GPS data in North America also confirms that land uplift becomes subsidence outside the former ice margin.<ref name="sella-etal-2007" />
===Global sea levels=== To form the ice sheets of the last Ice Age, water from the oceans evaporated, condensed as snow and was deposited as ice in high latitudes. Thus global sea level fell during glaciation.
The ice sheets at the last [[glacial maximum]] were so massive that global sea level fell by about 120 metres. Thus continental shelves were exposed and many islands became connected with the continents through dry land. This was the case between the British Isles and Europe ([[Doggerland]]), or between Taiwan, the Indonesian islands and Asia ([[Sundaland]]). A [[Beringia|sub-continent also existed between Siberia and Alaska]] that allowed the migration of people and animals during the last glacial maximum.<ref name="peltier-1998" />
The fall in sea level also affects the circulation of ocean currents and thus has important impact on climate during the glacial maximum.
During deglaciation, the melted ice water returns to the oceans, thus [[sea level rise|sea level in the ocean increases]] again. However, geological records of sea level changes show that the redistribution of the melted ice water is not the same everywhere in the oceans. In other words, depending upon the location, the rise in sea level at a certain site may be more than that at another site. This is due to the gravitational attraction between the mass of the melted water and the other masses, such as remaining ice sheets, glaciers, water masses and mantle rocks<ref name="peltier-1998" /> and the changes in centrifugal potential due to Earth's variable rotation.<ref name="mitrovica-milne-davis-2001">{{cite journal |last=Mitrovica |first=J.X. |author2=G.A. Milne |author3=J.L. Davis |last-author-amp=yes |date=2001 |title=Glacial isostatic adjustment on a rotating earth |journal=[[Geophysical Journal International]] |volume=147 |pages=562–578 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-246x.2001.01550.x |issue=3|bibcode = 2001GeoJI.147..562M }}</ref>
===Horizontal crustal motion===
Accompanying vertical motion is the horizontal motion of the crust. The BIFROST GPS network<ref name="bifrost" /> shows that the motion diverges from the centre of rebound.<ref name="johansson-2002" /> However, the largest horizontal velocity is found near the former ice margin.
The situation in North America is less certain; this is due to the sparse distribution of GPS stations in northern Canada, which is rather inaccessible.<ref name="sella-etal-2007" />
===Tilt=== The combination of horizontal and vertical motion changes the tilt of the surface. That is, locations farther north rise faster, an effect that becomes apparent in lakes. The bottoms of the lakes gradually tilt away from the direction of the former ice maximum, such that lake shores on the side of the maximum (typically north) recede and the opposite (southern) shores sink.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Seppä, H. |author2=M. Tikkanen & J.-P. Mäkiaho |title=Tilting of Lake Pielinen, eastern Finland – an example of extreme transgressions and regressions caused by differential post-glacial isostatic uplift |journal=Estonian Journal of Earth Sciences |volume=61 |issue=3 |date=2012 |pages=149–161 |doi=10.3176/earth.2012.3.02 }}</ref> This causes the formation of new rapids and rivers. For example, [[Lake Pielinen]], which is large (90 x 30 km) and oriented perpendicularly to the former ice margin, originally drained through an outlet in the middle of the lake near Nunnanlahti to Lake [[Höytiäinen]]. The change of tilt caused Pielinen to burst through the Uimaharju [[esker]] at the southwestern end of the lake, creating a new river ([[Pielisjoki]]) that runs to the sea via [[Lake Pyhäselkä]] to [[Lake Saimaa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joensuu.fi/jaakausi-paattyy-pielinen-syntyy|title=Jääkausi päättyy, Pielinen syntyy - joensuu.fi|author=|date=|website=www.joensuu.fi|accessdate=3 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170630235015/http://www.joensuu.fi/jaakausi-paattyy-pielinen-syntyy|archivedate=30 June 2017|df=}}</ref> The effects are similar to that concerning seashores, but occur above sea level. Tilting of land will also affect the flow of water in lakes and rivers in the future, and thus important for water resource management planning.
===Gravity field=== Ice, water and mantle rocks have [[mass]], and as they move around, they exert a gravitational pull on other masses towards them. Thus, the [[gravity field]], which is sensitive to all mass on the surface and within the Earth, is affected by the redistribution of ice/melted water on the surface of the Earth and the flow of mantle rocks within.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2010/12/ice-sheet-in-peril-gravity-to-rescue/|title=Ice sheet in peril? Gravity to the rescue|author=|date=2 December 2010|website=harvard.edu|accessdate=3 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814213410/http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2010/12/ice-sheet-in-peril-gravity-to-rescue/|archivedate=14 August 2017|df=}}</ref>
Today, more than 6000 years after the last deglaciation terminated, the flow of [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]] material back to the glaciated area causes the overall shape of the Earth to become less [[oblate spheroid|oblate]]. This change in the topography of Earth's surface affects the long-wavelength components of the gravity field. {{Citation needed|date=March 2010}}
The changing gravity field can be detected by repeated land measurements with absolute gravimeters and recently by the [[Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment|GRACE]] satellite mission.<ref name="grace">{{cite web |url=http://www.gfz-potsdam.de/pb1/op/grace/index_GRACE.html |title=GFZ Potsdam, Department 1: The GRACE Mission |accessdate=2008-05-09 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080508081548/http://www.gfz-potsdam.de/pb1/op/grace/index_GRACE.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-05-08}}</ref> The change in long-wavelength components of Earth's gravity field also perturbs the orbital motion of satellites and has been detected by [[LAGEOS]] satellite motion.<ref name="yoder-etal-1983">{{cite journal |last=Yoder |first=C. F. |display-authors=etal |date=1983 |title=J2-dot from Lageos and the non-tidal acceleration of earth rotation |journal=Nature |volume=303 |pages=757–762 |doi=10.1038/303757a0 |issue=5920|bibcode = 1983Natur.303..757Y }}</ref>
===Vertical datum=== The vertical [[Datum (geodesy)|datum]] is a theoretical reference surface for altitude measurement and plays vital roles in many human activities, including land surveying and construction of buildings and bridges. Since postglacial rebound continuously deforms the crustal surface and the gravitational field, the vertical datum needs to be redefined repeatedly through time.
===State of stress, intraplate earthquakes and volcanism=== According to the theory of [[plate tectonics]], plate-plate interaction results in earthquakes near plate boundaries. However, large earthquakes are found in intraplate environment like eastern Canada (up to M7) and northern Europe (up to M5) which are far away from present-day plate boundaries. An important intraplate earthquake was the magnitude 8 [[1812 New Madrid earthquake|New Madrid earthquake]] that occurred in mid-continental US in the year 1811.
Glacial loads provided more than 30 MPa of vertical stress in northern Canada and more than 20 MPa in northern Europe during glacial maximum. This vertical stress is supported by the mantle and the flexure of the [[lithosphere]]. Since the mantle and the lithosphere continuously respond to the changing ice and water loads, the state of stress at any location continuously changes in time. The changes in the orientation of the state of stress is recorded in the [[postglacial faults]] in southeastern Canada.<ref name="wu-1996">{{cite journal |last=Wu |first=P. |date=1996 |title=Changes in orientation of near-surface stress field as constraints to mantle viscosity and horizontal stress differences in Eastern Canada |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=23 |pages=2263–2266 |doi=10.1029/96GL02149 |bibcode=1996GeoRL..23.2263W |issue=17}}</ref> When the postglacial faults formed at the end of deglaciation 9000 years ago, the horizontal principal stress orientation was almost perpendicular to the former ice margin, but today the orientation is in the northeast-southwest, along the direction of [[seafloor spreading]] at the [[Mid-Atlantic Ridge]]. This shows that the stress due to postglacial rebound had played an important role at deglacial time, but has gradually relaxed so that tectonic stress has become more dominant today.
According to the [[Mohr–Coulomb theory]] of rock failure, large glacial loads generally suppress earthquakes, but rapid deglaciation promotes earthquakes. According to Wu & Hasagawa, the rebound stress that is available to trigger earthquakes today is of the order of 1 MPa.<ref name="wu-hasagawa-1996">{{cite journal |last=Wu |first=P. |author2=H.S. Hasegawa |date=1996 |title=Induced stresses and fault potential in Eastern Canada due to a realistic load: a preliminary analysis |journal=Geophysical Journal International |volume=127 |pages=215–229 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-246X.1996.tb01546.x|bibcode = 1996GeoJI.127..215W }}</ref> This stress level is not large enough to rupture intact rocks but is large enough to reactivate pre-existing faults that are close to failure. Thus, both postglacial rebound and past tectonics play important roles in today's intraplate earthquakes in eastern Canada and southeast US. Generally postglacial rebound stress could have triggered the intraplate earthquakes in eastern Canada and may have played some role in triggering earthquakes in the eastern US including the [[1811–12 New Madrid earthquakes|New Madrid earthquakes of 1811]].<ref name="wu-johnston-2000" /> The situation in northern Europe today is complicated by the current tectonic activities nearby and by coastal loading and weakening.
Increasing pressure due to the weight of the ice during glaciation may have suppressed melt generation and volcanic activities below Iceland and Greenland. On the other hand, decreasing pressure due to deglaciation can increase the melt production and volcanic activities by 20-30 times.<ref name="Jull-McKenzie-1996">{{cite journal |last=Jull |first=M. |author2=D. McKenzie |date=1996 |title=The effect of deglaciation on mantle melting beneath Iceland |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=101 |pages=21,815–21,828 |doi=10.1029/96jb01308 |bibcode=1996JGR...10121815J}}</ref>
===Recent global warming=== Recent [[global warming]] has caused mountain glaciers and the ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica to melt and global sea level to rise.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/warming-seas-and-melting-ice-sheets|title=Warming Seas, Melting Ice Sheets|first=Rob|last=Garner|date=25 August 2015|website=nasa.gov|accessdate=3 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180420173603/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/warming-seas-and-melting-ice-sheets/|archivedate=20 April 2018|df=}}</ref> Therefore, monitoring [[sea level rise]] and the mass balance of ice sheets and glaciers allows people to understand more about global warming.
Recent rise in sea levels has been monitored by tide gauges and satellite altimetry (e.g. [[TOPEX/Poseidon]]). As well as the addition of melted ice water from glaciers and ice sheets, recent sea level changes are affected by the thermal expansion of sea water due to global warming<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/tar/wg1/411.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-07-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831084509/https://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/tar/wg1/411.htm |archivedate=2017-08-31 |df= }}</ref>, sea level change due to deglaciation of the last glacial maximum (postglacial sea level change), deformation of the land and ocean floor and other factors. Thus, to understand global warming from sea level change, one must be able to separate all these factors, especially postglacial rebound, since it is one of the leading factors.
Mass changes of ice sheets can be monitored by measuring changes in the ice surface height, the deformation of the ground below and the changes in the gravity field over the ice sheet. Thus [[ICESat]], [[GPS]] and [[Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment|GRACE]] satellite mission are useful for such purpose.<ref name="wahr-wingham-bentley-2000">{{cite journal |last=Wahr |first=J. |author2=D. Wingham |author3=C. Bentley |last-author-amp=yes |date=2000 |title=A method of combining ICESat and GRACE satellite data to constrain Antarctic mass balance |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=105 |issue=B7 |pages=16279–16294 |doi=10.1029/2000JB900113 |bibcode=2000JGR...10516279W}}</ref> However, glacial isostatic adjustment of the ice sheets affect ground deformation and the gravity field today. Thus understanding glacial isostatic adjustment is important in monitoring recent global warming.
One of the possible impacts of global warming-triggered rebound may be more volcanic activity in previously ice-capped areas such as Iceland and Greenland.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/environment/|title=Environment|author=|date=30 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 May 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180323150919/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/environment/|archivedate=23 March 2018|df=}}</ref> It may also trigger intraplate earthquakes near the ice margins of Greenland and Antarctica.
==Applications== The speed and amount of postglacial rebound is determined by two factors: the [[viscosity]] or [[rheology]] (i.e., the flow) of the mantle, and the ice loading and unloading histories on the surface of Earth.
The viscosity of the [[mantle (geology)|mantle]] is important in understanding [[mantle convection]], [[plate tectonics]], dynamical processes in Earth, the thermal state and thermal evolution of Earth. However viscosity is difficult to observe because creep experiments of mantle rocks take thousands of years to observe and the ambient temperature and pressure conditions are not easy to attain for a long enough time. Thus, the observations of postglacial rebound provide a natural experiment to measure mantle rheology. Modelling of glacial isostatic adjustment addresses the question of how viscosity changes in the radial<ref name="peltier-1998" /><ref name="vermeersen-etal-1998">{{cite journal |last=Vermeersen |first=L.L.A. |display-authors=etal |date=1998 |title=Mantle viscosity inferences from joint inversion of Pleistocene deglaciation-induced changes in geopotential with a new SLR analysis and Polar Wander |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume=25 |issue=23 |pages=4261–4264 |doi=10.1029/1998GL900150 |bibcode=1998GeoRL..25.4261V}}</ref><ref name="kaufmann-lambeck-2002">{{cite journal |last=Kaufmann |first=G. |author2=K. Lambeck |date=2002 |title=Glacial isostatic adjustment and the radial viscosity profile from inverse modeling |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |volume=107 |issue=B11 |page=2280 |doi=10.1029/2001JB000941 |bibcode=2002JGRB..107.2280K|hdl=1885/92573 }}</ref> and lateral directions<ref name="wang-wu-2006">{{cite journal |last=Wang |first=H.S. |author2=P. Wu |date=2006 |title=Effects of lateral variations in lithospheric thickness and mantle viscosity on glacially induced relative sea levels and long wavelength gravity field in a spherical, self-gravitating Maxwell Earth |journal=Earth and Planetary Science Letters |volume=249 |pages=368–383 |doi=10.1016/j.epsl.2006.07.011 |bibcode=2006E&PSL.249..368W |issue=3–4}}</ref> and whether the flow law is linear, nonlinear,<ref name="karato-wu-1993">{{cite journal |last=Karato, S. |author2=P. Wu |date=1993 |title=Rheology of the upper mantle : a synthesis |journal=Science |volume=260 |pages=771–778 |doi=10.1126/science.260.5109.771 |pmid=17746109 |first1=S |issue=5109|bibcode = 1993Sci...260..771K }}</ref> or composite rheology.<ref name="vanderwal-etal-2010">{{cite journal |last=van der Wal, W. |display-authors=etal |date=2010 |title=Sea levels and uplift rate from composite rheology in glacial isostatic adjustment modeling |journal=Journal of Geodynamics |volume=50 |pages=38–48 |doi=10.1016/j.jog.2010.01.006 |bibcode = 2010JGeo...50...38V }}</ref>
Ice thickness histories are useful in the study of [[paleoclimatology]], [[glaciology]] and paleo-oceanography. Ice thickness histories are traditionally deduced from the three types of information: First, the sea level data at stable sites far away from the centers of [[deglaciation]] give an estimate of how much water entered the oceans or equivalently how much ice was locked up at glacial maximum. Secondly, the location and dates of [[Terminal Moraines|terminal moraines]] tell us the areal extent and retreat of past ice sheets. Physics of glaciers gives us the theoretical profile of ice sheets at equilibrium, it also says that the thickness and horizontal extent of [[:wikt:equilibrium|equilibrium]] ice sheets are closely related to the basal condition of the ice sheets. Thus the volume of ice locked up is proportional to their instantaneous area. Finally, the heights of ancient beaches in the sea level data and observed land uplift rates (e.g. from [[GPS]] or [[VLBI]]) can be used to [[Constraint (mathematics)|constrain]] local ice thickness. A popular ice model deduced this way is the ICE5G model.<ref name="peltier-2004">{{cite journal |last=Peltier |first=W. R. |date=2004 |title=Global glacial isostasy and the surface of the ice age earth: the ICE-5G (VM2) Model and GRACE |journal=Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences |volume=32 |pages=111–149 |doi=10.1146/annurev.earth.32.082503.144359 |bibcode=2004AREPS..32..111P}}</ref> Because the response of the Earth to changes in ice height is slow, it cannot record rapid fluctuation or surges of ice sheets, thus the ice sheet profiles deduced this way only gives the "average height" over a thousand years or so.<ref name="hughes-1998">{{Cite book |last=Hughes |first=T.|date=1998 |contribution=Tutorial on Strategies for using isostatic adjustments in models that reconstruct ice sheets during the last deglaciation |title=Dynamics of the Ice Age Earth: A Modern Perspective |editor-last=Wu |editor-first=P. |publisher=Trans Tech Publ. |location=Switzerland |pages=271–322 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
Glacial [[Isostasy|isostatic]] adjustment also plays an important role in understanding recent global warming and climate change.
==Discovery== Before the eighteenth century, it was thought, in [[Sweden]], that sea levels were falling. On the initiative of [[Anders Celsius]] a number of marks were made in rock on different locations along the Swedish coast. In 1765 it was possible to conclude that it was not a lowering of sea levels but an uneven rise of land. In 1865 [[Thomas Jamieson]] came up with a theory that the rise of land was connected with the ice age that had been first discovered in 1837. The theory was accepted after investigations by [[Gerard De Geer]] of old shorelines in Scandinavia published in 1890<ref>{{cite journal |last1=De Geer |first1=Gerard |title=Om Skandinaviens nivåförändringar under qvartärperioden |journal=Geologiska Föreningen i Stockholm Förhandlingar |date=1890 |volume=10 |issue=5 |pages=366–379 |doi=10.1080/11035898809444216}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=de Geer |first1=Gerard |title=Quaternary Sen-bottoms in Western Sweden |journal=Geologiska Föreningen i Stockholm Förhandlingar |date=1910 |volume=32 |issue=5 |pages=1139–1195 |doi=10.1080/11035891009442325}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=De Geer |first1=Gerard |title=Post-Algonkian Oscillations of Land in Feunoscandia |journal=Geologiska Föreningen i Stockholm Förhandlingar |date=1924 |volume=46 |issue=3-4 |pages=316–324 |doi=10.1080/11035892409442370}}</ref>.
==Legal implications== In areas where the rising of land is seen, it is necessary to define the exact limits of property. In Finland, the "new land" is legally the property of the owner of the water area, not any land owners on the shore. Therefore, if the owner of the land wishes to build a pier over the "new land", they need the permission of the owner of the (former) water area. The landowner of the shore may redeem the new land at market price.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vintti.yle.fi/yle.fi/kodinkaantopiiri/vesijatto.htm|title=Alluvion comes as a surprise| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716075322/http://yle.fi/kodinkaantopiiri/vesijatto.htm| archivedate=July 16, 2011}}</ref> Usually the owner of the water area is the [[partition unit]] of the landowners of the shores, a collective holding corporation.
==See also== *{{annotated link|Holocene glacial retreat}} *{{annotated link|Raised beach|aka=marine terrace}} *{{annotated link|Physical impacts of climate change}} *{{annotated link|Stress (mechanics)}}
